pull_request.title: Better filter the services we want to announce
pull_request.body:
This filters down the services to those which:

 * Have a `NodePort` defined since this is required for this method of announcement
 * Have a Label called `ServiceName` so we can be sure this is a service we want to announce

issue.title: WIP Supporting Mastodon-style actor profile attachments
issue.body: This PR adds support for Mastodon-style attachments on actors, which are most noticeably visible when viewing the profile of an actor. This supports, like Mastodon, up to 4 attachments on a single actor, and adds to the Settings form a few fields to make this editable. I am not a web UI expert so I can't say that this is the best way to do it, but it works well. It might be nice to start with one field and be able to click something to add more fields in the future. For now it just displays 4 empty fields when nothing is present. This has been tested running on my own Ktistec instance, and seems to do all the right things. The way the JSON post works to the settings controller is exactly the same as the HTML, which, while great for URL-encoded forms, is a little weird in JSON. Otherwise I think this is all a pretty good fit for how things are implemented.

comment.body: @toddsundsted I think this is ready to go!

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -606,8 +606,8 @@ module ActivityPub
           Tag::Mention.new(name: name, href: href)
         end,
         attachments: dig_values?(json, "https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#attachment") do |attachment|
-          url = attachment.dig?("https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#url").try(&.as_s)
-          media_type = attachment.dig?("https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#mediaType").try(&.as_s)
+          url = attachment["url"].try(&.as_s)
+          media_type = attachment["mediaType"].try(&.as_s)
comment.body:
These changes were necessitated by the change to `ld_json.cr`. The two things labeled attachment don't have the same schema. I think the Mastodon implementation on `actor` is non-standard. The activitiystreams context has
```
    "attachment": {
      "@id": "as:attachment",
      "@type": "@id"
    },
```

That doesn't match what Mastodon uses for actors.

If there is a better way to implement this, let me know. This is what I could figure out.

issue.title: Redaction via struct tags
issue.body:
Would you consider enabling redaction via struct tags? Ideally, I'd like to use it in combination with https://github.com/caarlos0/env like so:
```go
type Config struct {
	Username string `env:"USERNAME" envDefault:"mihai"`
	Password  string `env:"PASSWORD,required" rubberneck:"redact"`
}
```
Maybe the `rubberneck:"redact"` can be even more versatile, to allow users to specify the redaction symbol for example.

For prior art, I found https://github.com/leebenson/conform and I can get it to do redaction through a one liner like so:
```go
conform.AddSanitizer("redact", func(s string) string { return strings.Repeat("*", len(s)) })
```

But it would be so much nicer to have an all-in-one solution :)

comment.body: I like this idea. Sorry I didn't pay much attention to issues on this repo and just noticed this.

@@ -17,6 +17,13 @@
       br: a href=actor.display_link = actor.account_uri
       - if (summary = actor.summary.presence)
         br: == s summary
+	.ui.segment

comment.body: The implementation that is in this PR currently has them written and stored as plaintext to make editing easy, and converted to HTML links on presentation. Since Mastodon converts to HTML in the JSON as well, I also did that. If you were to enter HTML in the original input field, it will just return it back without any processing, because the link detector is intentionally only looking for strings that _start_ with what appears to be a proper URL. If you were to put your own HTML link in there, you would get that back unmodified next time you edit. With regard to federation, I feel like that's most easily solved with sanitizing on intake.

pull_request.title: Simple K8s API discovery method
pull_request.body:
This PR is a really simple attempt to build a discovery method that allows bridging between a Sidecar cluster and a Kubernetes cluster that has been configured to have a load balancer in front of it that matches the expected ports in the Sidecar cluster. This is useful for e.g. moving services from a Mesos cluster to a Kubernetes clusters and still being able to access them in the original cluster.

This implemenation use calls to the Kubernetes REST API using authentication provided from a token and `ca.crt` file as commonly mounted by Kubernetes for all pods. This is to get around loading the gigantic Kubernetes client library into sidecar and then having to maintain that.

issue.title: [Bug]: Created org is invisible to cf CLI
issue.body:
### What happened?

I successfully created an org from the `cf` cli:

```
cf -v create-org testing
```

This works:

```
... [ snip ] ...

$ RESPONSE: [2022-11-13T15:53:51Z]
HTTP/1.1 201 Created
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2022 15:53:51 GMT
Server: envoy
Vary: Accept-Encoding
X-Correlation-Id: f3501d8f-046b-43c2-ae2b-a9611fa44ba9
X-Envoy-Upstream-Service-Time: 25
{
  "created_at": "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z",
  "guid": "cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba",
  "links": {
    "self": {
      "href": "https://<REDACTED>/v3/organizations/cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba"
    }
  },
  "metadata": {
    "annotations": {},
    "labels": {}
  },
  "name": "testing",
  "relationships": {},
  "suspended": false,
  "updated_at": "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
}


OK
```

I can see the Kubernetes CRD entry:

```
$ kubectl get -n cf CFOrg
NAME                                          DISPLAY NAME   AGE
cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba   testing        117s
```

When I look at the detail for the entry, it claims the status is `Ready`:

```
$ kubectl get -n cf CFOrg -o yaml
apiVersion: v1
items:
- apiVersion: korifi.cloudfoundry.org/v1alpha1
  kind: CFOrg
  metadata:
    creationTimestamp: "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
    finalizers:
    - cfOrg.korifi.cloudfoundry.org
    generation: 1
    name: cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba
    namespace: cf
    resourceVersion: "159055"
    uid: 8611ccab-c673-4c74-85c2-74556860eab3
  spec:
    displayName: testing
  status:
    conditions:
    - lastTransitionTime: "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
      message: ""
      reason: Ready
      status: "True"
      type: Ready
    guid: cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba
kind: List
metadata:
  resourceVersion: ""
```

**However** the `cf` CLI cannot see the org:

```
$ cf -v orgs

... [snip] ...

RESPONSE: [2022-11-13T15:56:32Z]
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2022 15:56:32 GMT

comment.body:
@kieron-dev Thanks! This helps a lot. It appears that the default install instructions create the following binding:

```
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: RoleBinding
metadata:
  annotations:
    cloudfoundry.org/propagate-cf-role: "true"
    meta.helm.sh/release-name: korifi
    meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: korifi-system
  creationTimestamp: "2022-11-14T10:13:43Z"
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Helm
  name: default-admin-binding
  namespace: cf
  resourceVersion: "3544"
  uid: ce927288-89e8-4508-8a97-120f4e17ea6a
roleRef:
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: korifi-controllers-admin
subjects:
- apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: User
  name: cf-admin
```

based on the env var ```export ADMIN_USERNAME="cf-admin"```

But when I `cf curl /whoami` I am `{"name":"admin","kind":"User"}`. This mismatch appears to be the problem.

Now that I know what I am looking for thanks to your help, this was [explained in the initial setup](https://github.com/cloudfoundry/korifi/blob/main/INSTALL.md#initial-setup) but the consequences and takeaways weren't clear to me.

I attempted to create a new user role named `cf-admin` on the K8s RBAC side to make it work, but that was not successful. I tried to duplicate the existing RoleBinding and apply it for `admin`, again with no luck.

The thing that fixed it was changing the env var to `ADMIN_USERNAME=admin` and re-running the helm chart with `helm update --install`.

I will sort out the other permissions issues once I've evaluated things.

> By the way, in the next release we issue a warning visible in the CLI if the current user doesn't have any CF rolebindings so that people can check their setup: https://github.com/cloudfoundry/korifi/pull/1834.

That will help people out a lot, I think.

Thanks for your help!

issue.title: WIP Supporting Mastodon-style actor profile attachments
issue.body: This PR adds support for Mastodon-style attachments on actors, which are most noticeably visible when viewing the profile of an actor. This supports, like Mastodon, up to 4 attachments on a single actor, and adds to the Settings form a few fields to make this editable. I am not a web UI expert so I can't say that this is the best way to do it, but it works well. It might be nice to start with one field and be able to click something to add more fields in the future. For now it just displays 4 empty fields when nothing is present. This has been tested running on my own Ktistec instance, and seems to do all the right things. The way the JSON post works to the settings controller is exactly the same as the HTML, which, while great for URL-encoded forms, is a little weird in JSON. Otherwise I think this is all a pretty good fit for how things are implemented.

comment.body: @toddsundsted I think this is ready to go!

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -606,8 +606,8 @@ module ActivityPub
           Tag::Mention.new(name: name, href: href)
         end,
         attachments: dig_values?(json, "https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#attachment") do |attachment|
-          url = attachment.dig?("https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#url").try(&.as_s)
-          media_type = attachment.dig?("https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#mediaType").try(&.as_s)
+          url = attachment["url"].try(&.as_s)
+          media_type = attachment["mediaType"].try(&.as_s)
comment.body:
These changes were necessitated by the change to `ld_json.cr`. The two things labeled attachment don't have the same schema. I think the Mastodon implementation on `actor` is non-standard. The activitiystreams context has
```
    "attachment": {
      "@id": "as:attachment",
      "@type": "@id"
    },
```

That doesn't match what Mastodon uses for actors.

If there is a better way to implement this, let me know. This is what I could figure out.

issue.title: Redaction via struct tags
issue.body:
Would you consider enabling redaction via struct tags? Ideally, I'd like to use it in combination with https://github.com/caarlos0/env like so:
```go
type Config struct {
	Username string `env:"USERNAME" envDefault:"mihai"`
	Password  string `env:"PASSWORD,required" rubberneck:"redact"`
}
```
Maybe the `rubberneck:"redact"` can be even more versatile, to allow users to specify the redaction symbol for example.

For prior art, I found https://github.com/leebenson/conform and I can get it to do redaction through a one liner like so:
```go
conform.AddSanitizer("redact", func(s string) string { return strings.Repeat("*", len(s)) })
```

But it would be so much nicer to have an all-in-one solution :)

comment.body: I like this idea. Sorry I didn't pay much attention to issues on this repo and just noticed this.

comment.body: The implementation that is in this PR currently has them written and stored as plaintext to make editing easy, and converted to HTML links on presentation. Since Mastodon converts to HTML in the JSON as well, I also did that. If you were to enter HTML in the original input field, it will just return it back without any processing, because the link detector is intentionally only looking for strings that _start_ with what appears to be a proper URL. If you were to put your own HTML link in there, you would get that back unmodified next time you edit. With regard to federation, I feel like that's most easily solved with sanitizing on intake.

pull_request.title: Simple K8s API discovery method
pull_request.body:
This PR is a really simple attempt to build a discovery method that allows bridging between a Sidecar cluster and a Kubernetes cluster that has been configured to have a load balancer in front of it that matches the expected ports in the Sidecar cluster. This is useful for e.g. moving services from a Mesos cluster to a Kubernetes clusters and still being able to access them in the original cluster.

This implemenation use calls to the Kubernetes REST API using authentication provided from a token and `ca.crt` file as commonly mounted by Kubernetes for all pods. This is to get around loading the gigantic Kubernetes client library into sidecar and then having to maintain that.

issue.title: [Bug]: Created org is invisible to cf CLI
issue.body:
### What happened?

I successfully created an org from the `cf` cli:

```
cf -v create-org testing
```

This works:

```
... [ snip ] ...

$ RESPONSE: [2022-11-13T15:53:51Z]
HTTP/1.1 201 Created
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2022 15:53:51 GMT
Server: envoy
Vary: Accept-Encoding
X-Correlation-Id: f3501d8f-046b-43c2-ae2b-a9611fa44ba9
X-Envoy-Upstream-Service-Time: 25
{
  "created_at": "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z",
  "guid": "cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba",
  "links": {
    "self": {
      "href": "https://<REDACTED>/v3/organizations/cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba"
    }
  },
  "metadata": {
    "annotations": {},
    "labels": {}
  },
  "name": "testing",
  "relationships": {},
  "suspended": false,
  "updated_at": "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
}


OK
```

I can see the Kubernetes CRD entry:

```
$ kubectl get -n cf CFOrg
NAME                                          DISPLAY NAME   AGE
cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba   testing        117s
```

When I look at the detail for the entry, it claims the status is `Ready`:

```
$ kubectl get -n cf CFOrg -o yaml
apiVersion: v1
items:
- apiVersion: korifi.cloudfoundry.org/v1alpha1
  kind: CFOrg
  metadata:
    creationTimestamp: "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
    finalizers:
    - cfOrg.korifi.cloudfoundry.org
    generation: 1
    name: cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba
    namespace: cf
    resourceVersion: "159055"
    uid: 8611ccab-c673-4c74-85c2-74556860eab3
  spec:
    displayName: testing
  status:
    conditions:
    - lastTransitionTime: "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
      message: ""
      reason: Ready
      status: "True"
      type: Ready
    guid: cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba
kind: List
metadata:
  resourceVersion: ""
```

**However** the `cf` CLI cannot see the org:

```
$ cf -v orgs

... [snip] ...

RESPONSE: [2022-11-13T15:56:32Z]
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2022 15:56:32 GMT
Server: envoy
Vary: Accept-Encoding
X-Correlation-Id: 81e5db88-1119-4e1a-8caf-fd7e067eccf6
X-Envoy-Upstream-Service-Time: 5
{
  "pagination": {
    "first": {
      "href": "https://<REDACTED>/v3/organizations?order_by=name"
    },
    "last": {
      "href": "https://<REDACTED>/v3/organizations?order_by=name"
    },
    "next": null,
    "previous": null,
    "total_pages": 1,
    "total_results": 0
  },
  "resources": []
}


No orgs found.
```

### What you expected to happen

I expected to see the org that I just created

### Acceptance Criteria

GIVEN that I have created a CloudFoundry org 
WHEN I call `cf orgs`
THEN I see the org that I have created


### How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)

I followed the instructions here: https://github.com/cloudfoundry/korifi/blob/main/INSTALL.md

And then I took the actions described above, as part of the last step in the `INSTALL` guide

### Anything else we need to know?

The `cf` cli is running on Ubuntu 22.04 and was installed with the Debian package manager instructions: https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/cf-cli/install-go-cli.html

### Environment

Revision of codebase: 0.4.0
Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`):
```
Client Version: v1.25.3
Kustomize Version: v4.5.7
Server Version: v1.25.3
```
cf version: `8.5.0+73aa161.2022-09-12`
Cloud provider or hardware configuration: Hetzner cloud, `uname -a`: 
```
Linux thor 5.4.0-125-generic #141-Ubuntu SMP Wed Aug 10 13:42:03 UTC 2022 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
Others:

comment.body:
@kieron-dev Thanks! This helps a lot. It appears that the default install instructions create the following binding:

```
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: RoleBinding
metadata:
  annotations:
    cloudfoundry.org/propagate-cf-role: "true"
    meta.helm.sh/release-name: korifi
    meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: korifi-system
  creationTimestamp: "2022-11-14T10:13:43Z"
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Helm
  name: default-admin-binding
  namespace: cf
  resourceVersion: "3544"
  uid: ce927288-89e8-4508-8a97-120f4e17ea6a
roleRef:
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: korifi-controllers-admin
subjects:
- apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: User
  name: cf-admin
```

based on the env var ```export ADMIN_USERNAME="cf-admin"```

But when I `cf curl /whoami` I am `{"name":"admin","kind":"User"}`. This mismatch appears to be the problem.

Now that I know what I am looking for thanks to your help, this was [explained in the initial setup](https://github.com/cloudfoundry/korifi/blob/main/INSTALL.md#initial-setup) but the consequences and takeaways weren't clear to me.

I attempted to create a new user role named `cf-admin` on the K8s RBAC side to make it work, but that was not successful. I tried to duplicate the existing RoleBinding and apply it for `admin`, again with no luck.

The thing that fixed it was changing the env var to `ADMIN_USERNAME=admin` and re-running the helm chart with `helm update --install`.

I will sort out the other permissions issues once I've evaluated things.

> By the way, in the next release we issue a warning visible in the CLI if the current user doesn't have any CF rolebindings so that people can check their setup: https://github.com/cloudfoundry/korifi/pull/1834.

That will help people out a lot, I think.

Thanks for your help!

issue.title: WIP Supporting Mastodon-style actor profile attachments
issue.body: This PR adds support for Mastodon-style attachments on actors, which are most noticeably visible when viewing the profile of an actor. This supports, like Mastodon, up to 4 attachments on a single actor, and adds to the Settings form a few fields to make this editable. I am not a web UI expert so I can't say that this is the best way to do it, but it works well. It might be nice to start with one field and be able to click something to add more fields in the future. For now it just displays 4 empty fields when nothing is present. This has been tested running on my own Ktistec instance, and seems to do all the right things. The way the JSON post works to the settings controller is exactly the same as the HTML, which, while great for URL-encoded forms, is a little weird in JSON. Otherwise I think this is all a pretty good fit for how things are implemented.

comment.body: @toddsundsted I think this is ready to go!

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -606,8 +606,8 @@ module ActivityPub
           Tag::Mention.new(name: name, href: href)
         end,
         attachments: dig_values?(json, "https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#attachment") do |attachment|
-          url = attachment.dig?("https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#url").try(&.as_s)
-          media_type = attachment.dig?("https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#mediaType").try(&.as_s)
+          url = attachment["url"].try(&.as_s)
+          media_type = attachment["mediaType"].try(&.as_s)
comment.body:
These changes were necessitated by the change to `ld_json.cr`. The two things labeled attachment don't have the same schema. I think the Mastodon implementation on `actor` is non-standard. The activitiystreams context has
```
    "attachment": {
      "@id": "as:attachment",
      "@type": "@id"
    },
```

That doesn't match what Mastodon uses for actors.

If there is a better way to implement this, let me know. This is what I could figure out.

issue.title: Redaction via struct tags
issue.body:
Would you consider enabling redaction via struct tags? Ideally, I'd like to use it in combination with https://github.com/caarlos0/env like so:
```go
type Config struct {
	Username string `env:"USERNAME" envDefault:"mihai"`
	Password  string `env:"PASSWORD,required" rubberneck:"redact"`
}
```
Maybe the `rubberneck:"redact"` can be even more versatile, to allow users to specify the redaction symbol for example.

For prior art, I found https://github.com/leebenson/conform and I can get it to do redaction through a one liner like so:
```go
conform.AddSanitizer("redact", func(s string) string { return strings.Repeat("*", len(s)) })
```

But it would be so much nicer to have an all-in-one solution :)

comment.body: The implementation that is in this PR currently has them written and stored as plaintext to make editing easy, and converted to HTML links on presentation. Since Mastodon converts to HTML in the JSON as well, I also did that. If you were to enter HTML in the original input field, it will just return it back without any processing, because the link detector is intentionally only looking for strings that _start_ with what appears to be a proper URL. If you were to put your own HTML link in there, you would get that back unmodified next time you edit. With regard to federation, I feel like that's most easily solved with sanitizing on intake.

pull_request.title: Simple K8s API discovery method
pull_request.body:
This PR is a really simple attempt to build a discovery method that allows bridging between a Sidecar cluster and a Kubernetes cluster that has been configured to have a load balancer in front of it that matches the expected ports in the Sidecar cluster. This is useful for e.g. moving services from a Mesos cluster to a Kubernetes clusters and still being able to access them in the original cluster.

This implemenation use calls to the Kubernetes REST API using authentication provided from a token and `ca.crt` file as commonly mounted by Kubernetes for all pods. This is to get around loading the gigantic Kubernetes client library into sidecar and then having to maintain that.

issue.title: [Bug]: Created org is invisible to cf CLI
issue.body:
### What happened?

I successfully created an org from the `cf` cli:

```
cf -v create-org testing
```

This works:

```
... [ snip ] ...

$ RESPONSE: [2022-11-13T15:53:51Z]
HTTP/1.1 201 Created
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2022 15:53:51 GMT
Server: envoy
Vary: Accept-Encoding
X-Correlation-Id: f3501d8f-046b-43c2-ae2b-a9611fa44ba9
X-Envoy-Upstream-Service-Time: 25
{
  "created_at": "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z",
  "guid": "cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba",
  "links": {
    "self": {
      "href": "https://<REDACTED>/v3/organizations/cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba"
    }
  },
  "metadata": {
    "annotations": {},
    "labels": {}
  },
  "name": "testing",
  "relationships": {},
  "suspended": false,
  "updated_at": "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
}


OK
```

I can see the Kubernetes CRD entry:

```
$ kubectl get -n cf CFOrg
NAME                                          DISPLAY NAME   AGE
cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba   testing        117s
```

When I look at the detail for the entry, it claims the status is `Ready`:

```
$ kubectl get -n cf CFOrg -o yaml
apiVersion: v1
items:
- apiVersion: korifi.cloudfoundry.org/v1alpha1
  kind: CFOrg
  metadata:
    creationTimestamp: "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
    finalizers:
    - cfOrg.korifi.cloudfoundry.org
    generation: 1
    name: cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba
    namespace: cf
    resourceVersion: "159055"
    uid: 8611ccab-c673-4c74-85c2-74556860eab3
  spec:
    displayName: testing
  status:
    conditions:
    - lastTransitionTime: "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
      message: ""
      reason: Ready
      status: "True"
      type: Ready
    guid: cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba
kind: List
metadata:
  resourceVersion: ""
```

**However** the `cf` CLI cannot see the org:

```
$ cf -v orgs

... [snip] ...

RESPONSE: [2022-11-13T15:56:32Z]
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2022 15:56:32 GMT
Server: envoy
Vary: Accept-Encoding
X-Correlation-Id: 81e5db88-1119-4e1a-8caf-fd7e067eccf6
X-Envoy-Upstream-Service-Time: 5
{
  "pagination": {
    "first": {
      "href": "https://<REDACTED>/v3/organizations?order_by=name"
    },
    "last": {
      "href": "https://<REDACTED>/v3/organizations?order_by=name"
    },
    "next": null,
    "previous": null,
    "total_pages": 1,
    "total_results": 0
  },
  "resources": []
}


No orgs found.
```

### What you expected to happen

I expected to see the org that I just created

### Acceptance Criteria

GIVEN that I have created a CloudFoundry org 
WHEN I call `cf orgs`
THEN I see the org that I have created


### How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)

I followed the instructions here: https://github.com/cloudfoundry/korifi/blob/main/INSTALL.md

And then I took the actions described above, as part of the last step in the `INSTALL` guide

### Anything else we need to know?

The `cf` cli is running on Ubuntu 22.04 and was installed with the Debian package manager instructions: https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/cf-cli/install-go-cli.html

### Environment

Revision of codebase: 0.4.0
Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`):
```
Client Version: v1.25.3
Kustomize Version: v4.5.7
Server Version: v1.25.3
```
cf version: `8.5.0+73aa161.2022-09-12`
Cloud provider or hardware configuration: Hetzner cloud, `uname -a`: 
```
Linux thor 5.4.0-125-generic #141-Ubuntu SMP Wed Aug 10 13:42:03 UTC 2022 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
Others:

comment.body:
@kieron-dev Thanks! This helps a lot. It appears that the default install instructions create the following binding:

```
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: RoleBinding
metadata:
  annotations:
    cloudfoundry.org/propagate-cf-role: "true"
    meta.helm.sh/release-name: korifi
    meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: korifi-system
  creationTimestamp: "2022-11-14T10:13:43Z"
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Helm
  name: default-admin-binding
  namespace: cf
  resourceVersion: "3544"
  uid: ce927288-89e8-4508-8a97-120f4e17ea6a
roleRef:
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: korifi-controllers-admin
subjects:
- apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: User
  name: cf-admin
```

based on the env var ```export ADMIN_USERNAME="cf-admin"```

But when I `cf curl /whoami` I am `{"name":"admin","kind":"User"}`. This mismatch appears to be the problem.

Now that I know what I am looking for thanks to your help, this was [explained in the initial setup](https://github.com/cloudfoundry/korifi/blob/main/INSTALL.md#initial-setup) but the consequences and takeaways weren't clear to me.

I attempted to create a new user role named `cf-admin` on the K8s RBAC side to make it work, but that was not successful. I tried to duplicate the existing RoleBinding and apply it for `admin`, again with no luck.

The thing that fixed it was changing the env var to `ADMIN_USERNAME=admin` and re-running the helm chart with `helm update --install`.

I will sort out the other permissions issues once I've evaluated things.

> By the way, in the next release we issue a warning visible in the CLI if the current user doesn't have any CF rolebindings so that people can check their setup: https://github.com/cloudfoundry/korifi/pull/1834.

That will help people out a lot, I think.

Thanks for your help!

issue.title: [Bug]: Created org is invisible to cf CLI
issue.body:
### What happened?

I successfully created an org from the `cf` cli:

```
cf -v create-org testing
```

This works:

```
... [ snip ] ...

$ RESPONSE: [2022-11-13T15:53:51Z]
HTTP/1.1 201 Created
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2022 15:53:51 GMT
Server: envoy
Vary: Accept-Encoding
X-Correlation-Id: f3501d8f-046b-43c2-ae2b-a9611fa44ba9
X-Envoy-Upstream-Service-Time: 25
{
  "created_at": "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z",
  "guid": "cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba",
  "links": {
    "self": {
      "href": "https://<REDACTED>/v3/organizations/cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba"
    }
  },
  "metadata": {
    "annotations": {},
    "labels": {}
  },
  "name": "testing",
  "relationships": {},
  "suspended": false,
  "updated_at": "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
}


OK
```

I can see the Kubernetes CRD entry:

```
$ k8 get -n cf CFOrg
NAME                                          DISPLAY NAME   AGE
cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba   testing        117s
```

When I look at the detail for the entry, it claims the status is `Ready`:

```
$ k8 get -n cf CFOrg -o yaml
apiVersion: v1
items:
- apiVersion: korifi.cloudfoundry.org/v1alpha1
  kind: CFOrg
  metadata:
    creationTimestamp: "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
    finalizers:
    - cfOrg.korifi.cloudfoundry.org
    generation: 1
    name: cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba
    namespace: cf
    resourceVersion: "159055"
    uid: 8611ccab-c673-4c74-85c2-74556860eab3
  spec:
    displayName: testing
  status:
    conditions:
    - lastTransitionTime: "2022-11-13T15:53:51Z"
      message: ""
      reason: Ready
      status: "True"
      type: Ready
    guid: cf-org-0405d7e3-44fa-47e2-a52a-834f6d7ed9ba
kind: List
metadata:
  resourceVersion: ""
```

**However** the `cf` CLI cannot see the org:

```
$ cf -v orgs

... [snip] ...

RESPONSE: [2022-11-13T15:56:32Z]
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Sun, 13 Nov 2022 15:56:32 GMT
Server: envoy
Vary: Accept-Encoding
X-Correlation-Id: 81e5db88-1119-4e1a-8caf-fd7e067eccf6
X-Envoy-Upstream-Service-Time: 5
{
  "pagination": {
    "first": {
      "href": "https://<REDACTED>/v3/organizations?order_by=name"
    },
    "last": {
      "href": "https://<REDACTED>/v3/organizations?order_by=name"
    },
    "next": null,
    "previous": null,
    "total_pages": 1,
    "total_results": 0
  },
  "resources": []
}


No orgs found.
```

### What you expected to happen

I expected to see the org that I just created

### Acceptance Criteria

GIVEN that I have created a CloudFoundry org 
WHEN I call `cf orgs`
THEN I see the org that I have created


### How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)

I followed the instructions here: https://github.com/cloudfoundry/korifi/blob/main/INSTALL.md

And then I took the actions described above, as part of the last step in the `INSTALL` guide

### Anything else we need to know?

The `cf` cli is running on Ubuntu 22.04 and was installed with the Debian package manager instructions: https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/cf-cli/install-go-cli.html

### Environment

Revision of codebase: 0.4.0
Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`):
```
Client Version: v1.25.3
Kustomize Version: v4.5.7
Server Version: v1.25.3
```
Cloud provider or hardware configuration: Hetzner cloud, `uname -a`: 
```
Linux thor 5.4.0-125-generic #141-Ubuntu SMP Wed Aug 10 13:42:03 UTC 2022 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
